awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Community Input to Architectural  Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research investigates how labor was organized to produce and maintain architecture. When people construct buildings, they work together in groups that may consist of friends, relatives, neighbors, or professionals. Examining the organization of architectural labor can reveal how people interact with their communities and how they manage their time and resources. Information on architectural production can also supplement studies of social organization, economic and non-architectural labor strategies, and site occupation histories. This research expands on traditional archaeological studies of architecture with a special focus on the earthen materials used in construction. Earthen plasters and mortars have the potential to provide significant information about the technological and materials knowledge of builders. In focusing on earthen materials in addition to other elements of architecture, this research will establish analytical and sampling strategies that can guide historic preservation planning, produce a record of site condition baselines useful for monitoring and stabilizing the non-renewable archaeological record held in trust for the public by the National Park Service (NPS), and supplements previously conducted architectural analyses.  Detailed analyses of plasters also contribute to broader discussions on the impact of environmental variability on cultural resources. The study provides training for the doctoral student, who is a member of the Absentee Shawnee Tribe of Oklahoma and will also provide training in architectural documentation and operation of laboratory equipment for an undergraduate student.

The doctoral student will document and examine architectural elements (including walls, roofs, floors, doorways, plasters, and hearths) to identify patterns in material use, construction techniques, and plaster recipes at two cliff dwellings in Navajo National Monument, on the Navajo Nation. Both villages were occupied for less than forty years. The co-PI and an undergraduate student assistant studying archaeology will document and photograph the architecture. After completion of the documentation, small samples of selected earthen construction materials (such as plasters and mortars) will be collected and analyzed using a combination of geochemical and petrographic methods. The goal of the laboratory analyses is to refine knowledge of the technological choices made by the people who lived at these sites, the extent to which people shared their construction knowledge and plaster recipes with their neighbors, and to evaluate the diversity of materials used in construction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Katharine Williams has completed data collection and analyses for her dissertation "Architecture and the Organization of Labor at Tsegi Phase (AD 1250-1300) Cliff Dwellings, Navajo National Monument" with support by a National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. The goal of this research was to examine how the people that built these communities might have worked together for construction or as individual social units for construction. This was done by assessing how individual architectural elements (such as floors, walls, plasters, roofs, and doorways) share or don't share attributes (such as raw material type, construction processes, and final appearance). The extent to which attributes are shared between architectural elements associated with individual households or social units reflects the extent to which those builders shared construction practices. Shared practices indicate that builders worked together in some capacity while unique practices indicate that builders worked independently.

This project had two phases. Phase one was primarily field focused and involved several visits to each community to document the architecture and to identify earthen architectural materials for additional study. This portion of the project concluded with a final visit to each community to collect a limited set of small (~1 cm2) samples of earthen construction materials for laboratory analysis to help refine understandings of recipes used in construction. Phase two of the project focused on those laboratory analyses. The NSF funding period covered some of the field visits for earthen architectural material (plasters, mortars, and daubs) sampling as well as laboratory analyses of said samples and the beginning stages of the writing process. An undergraduate assistant was hired to work with the co-PI in processing and organizing the field documentation and the micromorphological data. During this period Williams was able to collect all earthen material samples required for the research as well as characterize those samples using scanning electron microscopy, x ray diffraction, and optical microscopy. 

Field research was conducted at Betatakin and Keet Seel, Navajo National Monument, Arizona. Laboratory research and writing took place at the University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. At the time of this report submission Williams is in the process of writing the final chapters of the dissertation. Upon completion, this dissertation will be available through the University of New Mexico's LoboVault as well as through ProQuest. This dissertation will be completed this spring. Preliminary results suggest that this approach to understanding architecture through the lens of shared practices does provide insight into how builders organized themselves to build their communities.

This research is an important contribution to the field of archaeology. It takes a novel approach to the interpretation of architecture and the built environment with its emphasis on the information potential of earthen architectural materials in conjunction with the more traditional aspects of architectural analysis (with its focus on the structural components of buildings). The careful study of earthen architectural materials has additional benefits beyond furthering archaeological understandings of labor. In the US Southwest, builders that work with traditional building materials (earth, stone, and wood) usually maintain annual or even sub-annual cycles of earthen material replacement and repair, especially for earthen plasters, as these materials constitute the primary defense against weathering of buildings. When structures are no longer regularly maintained or when climatic conditions change such that structures are exposed to more frequent rainfall events, architecture can deteriorate rapidly. Understanding how builders designed their earthen mixes hundreds of years ago such that their buildings are still standing today can help us understand how to design earthen mixes for present and future use. In addition, in the face of a changing climate, documenting architecture in its current condition provides an invaluable record for future generations.
